text: simone romero profiles american laurie
Berenson now on parole after serving
time for collaborating with a Marxist
terrorist group in Peru I totally
understand that people feel a strong
rejection to someone who represents
terrorism in 1995 the Peruvian
government arrested Laurie Berenson the
American who became notorious for
collaborating with a Marxist rebel group
called the Tupac Amaru revolutionary
movement investigators found that she
rented a house in Lima for the group
where they stored ammunition and plotted
to take the Peruvian Congress hostage
now on parole after more than fourteen
years in prison
she continues to claim that she never
planned to commit any violence I shared
ideological things that I never had
anything to do with either plans to do a
violent act or a part in a violent death
Berenson is reviled within Peru because
much of the country views her as a
symbol of the turmoil that afflicted the
country in the 1980s and 90s when almost
70,000 Peruvians were killed in the war
involving her group and another
insurgency the Shining Path I really
wasn't that much of a monster than this
you know I might have had an incorrect
ideology or an incorrect manner of
seeing life but I wasn't an assassin and
I wasn't a monster Berenson may still
end up back behind bars because a
government prosecutor is appealing her
parole but for now
she spends her days rediscovering life
after a decade and a half in prison
caring for her son Salvador who she had
in prison with a former member of the
tupac amaru group and trying to piece
together a profession as a translator
I'm saddened and I'm sorry that I have
been part of something that was
considered so damaging you know when I
was young I thought I had this moral
obligation to do things for others and I
don't think that was bad so I assume the
consequences of it instead of saying
well I shouldn't have done it in
